issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?
Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw:
I share your pain, dan.  I've been able to pick it up a few times, but inevitably, with any sort of moving around, I find that it will slip through my grasp.  We've contemplated having to have a two hand grab; that seems counter to the spirit of the challenge.

I'm not sure what would improve it; I've explored trying to modify the hand controller to allow for independent control of Pitch2 and Pitch3 on the fingers (if the grip can be less curved, it could potentially hold faster).  It's not clear that such a modification would even be permitted. 

The other thought I had was to increase the friction a bit; that would probably make it work for me.

And, then, finally, I would like all the work surfaces to be higher; I think that would help enormously.
content.html:
I share your pain, dan. I've been able to pick it up a few times, but inevitably, with any sort of moving around, I find that it will slip through my grasp. We've contemplated having to have a two hand grab; that seems counter to the spirit of the challenge.

I'm not sure what would improve it; I've explored trying to modify the hand controller to allow for independent control of Pitch2 and Pitch3 on the fingers (if the grip can be less curved, it could potentially hold faster). It's not clear that such a modification would even be permitted.

The other thought I had was to increase the friction a bit; that would probably make it work for me.

And, then, finally, I would like all the work surfaces to be higher; I think that would help enormously.

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw:
We're open to changing problematic models; it would help to see that video, but it's not working for me.

I've been able to grasp both tools and wave them around using the keyboard teleop. At times it did feel like the grip was unsteady, but I imagined that was due to my naive approach and teams would probably be working on fancy code to carefully place each finger around the tool.
content.html:
We're open to changing problematic models; it would help to see that video, but it's not working for me.

I've been able to grasp both tools and wave them around using the keyboard teleop. At times it did feel like the grip was unsteady, but I imagined that was due to my naive approach and teams would probably be working on fancy code to carefully place each finger around the tool.

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw: There aren't actuators for the Pitch2 and Pitch3 joints, unfortunately. There are pulleys connecting the motion of `Pitch1` to `Pitch2` and `Pitch3` that are simulated in gazebo with PD controllers. So the 5 joint commands for each hand are all that are on the real robot.
content.html: There aren't actuators for the Pitch2 and Pitch3 joints, unfortunately. There are pulleys connecting the motion of Pitch1 to Pitch2 and Pitch3 that are simulated in gazebo with PD controllers. So the 5 joint commands for each hand are all that are on the real robot.

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw:
I just downloaded the file to another computer from this site and it played fine on VLC player in Ubuntu, so I don't know why it is giving you trouble.  Can you try it again?

@[Jeremy White](https://bitbucket.org/knitfoo/) YES.  The table is so low that we are having to do all sorts of machinations with bending and twisting to reach the objects.  And as [Steven](https://bitbucket.org/scpeters/) points out, we have limited control of the joints in the hands.
content.html:
I just downloaded the file to another computer from this site and it played fine on VLC player in Ubuntu, so I don't know why it is giving you trouble. Can you try it again?

@Jeremy White YES. The table is so low that we are having to do all sorts of machinations with bending and twisting to reach the objects. And as Steven points out, we have limited control of the joints in the hands.

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw:
In case it helps, I can play the video fine with mplayer. 

Louise, I'd be surprised it you were able to do that without being in god mode, against the current positions those tools use on that table.

I was able to do it fine in god mode, and I've had good luck doing it when I place it on the table outside the habitat.  But when it's at the 'real' position, I find the extent is sufficiently hard that I cannot get the angles I need to grip it.

(I rate three modes:  'real' mode, where gazebo is minimized, 'demi-god' mode, where I get to use gazebo, but cannot move anything, and then 'god' mode, where I can use gazebo to re position it).
content.html:
In case it helps, I can play the video fine with mplayer.

Louise, I'd be surprised it you were able to do that without being in god mode, against the current positions those tools use on that table.

I was able to do it fine in god mode, and I've had good luck doing it when I place it on the table outside the habitat. But when it's at the 'real' position, I find the extent is sufficiently hard that I cannot get the angles I need to grip it.

(I rate three modes: 'real' mode, where gazebo is minimized, 'demi-god' mode, where I get to use gazebo, but cannot move anything, and then 'god' mode, where I can use gazebo to re position it).

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw:
Just to clarify, @knitfoo, the issue of not having a good angle to grip the tool comes from the random tool orientation, or from the table height? 

I think the orientation could be solved by pushing the tool before grasping it.
content.html:
Just to clarify, @knitfoo, the issue of not having a good angle to grip the tool comes from the random tool orientation, or from the table height?

I think the orientation could be solved by pushing the tool before grasping it.

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw: I have to confess I haven't rigorously understood where the tool placements will be; I've just gone into a few random worlds and tried it.  It may be that I've been unlucky and had particularly hard placements.  But each time, I find that I'm at maximum extent, basically brushing the tool with finger tips.  And yes, it's conceivable that I could push the tool to a different position, and it's also conceivable that I could grab it with both hands.    A little extra table height, or placing the tools a little closer to the table edge; either of those would be a huge help.  And, again, a bit more friction may be all I really need.
content.html: I have to confess I haven't rigorously understood where the tool placements will be; I've just gone into a few random worlds and tried it. It may be that I've been unlucky and had particularly hard placements. But each time, I find that I'm at maximum extent, basically brushing the tool with finger tips. And yes, it's conceivable that I could push the tool to a different position, and it's also conceivable that I could grab it with both hands. A little extra table height, or placing the tools a little closer to the table edge; either of those would be a huge help. And, again, a bit more friction may be all I really need.

issue.title: Is the leak detector supposed to be this hard to grab?

content.raw: The tool orientation plays a part certainly, but the low table is a big factor.  We have to bend, twist, and lower Val to the point of instability to achieve much reach onto that table.
content.html: The tool orientation plays a part certainly, but the low table is a big factor. We have to bend, twist, and lower Val to the point of instability to achieve much reach onto that table.
